channel.title: Confessions of a Pioneer Woman | Ree Drummond - Full RSS Feed

item.title: Tell Me ‘Bout the Good Ol’ Days
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: The boys woke up early yesterday morning because they couldn’t wait to get all spiffed up for church. They love getting dressed up; have I ever told you this? They willingly go shopping for clothes when the need arises and nothing makes them happier than putting on a pair of pants and a nice shirt and looking all dapper. I’m 100% convinced this is the direct result of the fact that they live on a…
item.content:encoded:
The boys woke up early yesterday morning because they couldn’t wait to get all spiffed up for church. They love getting dressed up; have I ever told you this? They willingly go shopping for clothes when the need arises and nothing makes them happier than putting on a pair of pants and a nice shirt and looking all dapper.

I’m 100% convinced this is the direct result of the fact that they live on a cattle ranch and have been coated in mud and manure for approximately 87% of their lives.

I put together Easter baskets for the kids because it’s a tradition, and if I suspend any of these traditions it means my kids are too old for those traditions, and from there it’s just a slippery slope until they’re grown and gone and cobwebs form in my hair.

Here’s what I put in each basket:

* 1 small stuffed animal.
* 1 pair of sunglasses, which I propped on the face of each small stuffed animal.
* 1 OKC Thunder t-shirt. Because Thunder Up. That’s why.
* 1 Cadbury Creme Egg
* Minus 1 Cadbury Creme Egg, because I ate one of the eggs Saturday night and decided to be fair, I needed to remove the rest of the eggs. And hide them in my bedside table.
* 1 pair of flip flops. Perfect for our gravel roads!
* Lots of miscellaneous candy.
* Minus some of the miscellaneous candy.

It was a Walmart kinda Easter!

Then we went to church and it was beautiful.

There’s so much I love about Easter.

 
 
After church we went to Tim and Missy’s house for our big traditional Easter meal.

Ham, you ask?

Well…

Not exactly.

 
 
 
Steaks! For Easter brunch! What’s the world coming to?

 
 
 
Don’t ask. Long story.

 
 
 
In addition to some delicious sides, we also had this cake, which we decided to name “Earthquake Cake.”

Don’t ask. Long story.

 
 
 
Missy’s always wearing pretty earrings.

Don’t ask. Long story.

Not really. I just felt like saying it again.

 
 
 
After lunch, the kids played basketball.

 
 
 
Aw, my sweet baby and my sweet niece. They have so much fun together!

 
 
 
At least…at least I think they have fun together.

 
 
 
Um…is everything okay over there?

 
 
 
Yes, Aunt Ree—everything’s great!

Okay, just checking/

 
 
So then, Missy, my mother-in-law, and Edna Mae (Marlboro Man’s grandmother) and I found ourselves sitting in the dining room and visiting about the old days. Edna Mae talked about the days when she used to have a wood burning stove, and she’d cook a huge breakfast and lunch every day for her husband and ranch workers, and after lunch was over she’d do the dishes with her two daughters, then she’d pass out from exhaustion while they went swimming in the water hole.

She also talked about the time before she was married when she and her best friend would saddle their horses and ride seven miles to town to the drugstore, where they’d spend all their money (probably twenty cents between them) on sodas because the soda jerk (that’s what they used to call people who made the soda drinks) was a really cute and nice fella.

Then they’d ride home seven miles, giggling and recounting all the conversation they’d just had with the cute and nice soda jerk.

Oh, how I love Edna Mae. This Saturday’s Food Network episode is all about her. It’s one of my favorites so far.

My mother-in-law talked about the old days, too—about her childhood in the country, about her propensity for finding quiet plots of pasture and lying down with her Border Collie and gazing at the sky, and about the early days of her marriage, when she hardly saw Marlboro Man’s dad because they didn’t have horse trailers back then and he’d have to sometimes leave at three in the morning to ride his horse to the place he needed to go, and he sometimes wouldn’t get home till nine at night.

Missy and I talked about the old days, too.

But it was about things like how Walmart was just Walmart back when we were kids.

Not Walmart Supercenter.

 
 
And my mother-in-law laughed…which I think is when she is at her most beautiful.

Fortunately for her, she laughs all the time!

item.title: Easter Leftover Sandwich
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Got leftover Easter eggs? Got leftover Easter ham? Got a hearty appetite? Good! You’ve come to the right place! I made this big honkin’ sandwich a few months ago, and it’ll be in my holiday cookbook, which is coming this fall assuming I finish said holiday cookbook. Whee! Oh, and I’d better go cook now. Anyway, as I’ve explained to you before, it’s very difficult for me to save recipes for my cookbooks and not…
item.content:encoded:
Got leftover Easter eggs?

Got leftover Easter ham?

Got a hearty appetite?

Good! You’ve come to the right place!

I made this big honkin’ sandwich a few months ago, and it’ll be in my holiday cookbook, which is coming this fall assuming I finish said holiday cookbook. Whee! Oh, and I’d better go cook now.

Anyway, as I’ve explained to you before, it’s very difficult for me to save recipes for my cookbooks and not share them here. It’s a clinical affliction known as Saverecipesformycookbookitis.

I’ve got a wicked case of it, man.

 
First of all, have you ever done this? If not, get ready to be inspired to make egg salad every day for the rest of your life. Peel your hard-boiled eggs and place it on top of a cooling rack you’d use for cookies or cakes. (The rack should be resting over a bowl.)

 
 
 
Use the palm of your (very clean) hand and pop it right through!

 
 
 
Then just keep doing it egg by egg…

 
 
 
Until you have a bowl full of perfectly “chopped up” eggs.

 
 
 
Add mayonnaise, grainy mustard, Worcestershire, salt, and pepper. You can also add chopped up pickles, olives, splash in a little pickle juice, Sriracha, Tabasco…anything you want to give it the flavor you’re lookin’ for.

 
 
 
Stir it together, making sure to taste and adjust seasonings to make sure it’s just right!

 
 
 
To build the sandwich, halve the bread of your choice (I used a Kaiser roll) and spread one half with Dijon…

 
 
 
Then spread the other half with mayonnaise and sprinkle it with salt and pepper.

 
 
 
On the half with the Dijon, lay a slice of cheese. I used Swiss.

 
 
 
Then lay on some of the leftover Easter ham.

 
 
 
Meanwhile, on the mayo half, lay a bunch of luscious avocado pieces…

 
 
 
And a few very thin slices of red onion, as well as two or three slices of Roma tomato, which I don’t have a photo of, because I’m an airhead.

 
 
 
Grab a big scoop of egg salad…

 
 
 
Plop it on top of the tomatoes…

 
 
 
And spread it out into an even layer.

 
 
 
Finally, lay on whatever lettuce or greens you have: green leaf, Romaine, or just mixed greens. Spinach or arugula would also be divine!

 
 
 
Then take a deep breath and put the two halves together.

 
 
 
Serve it with chips…and a very, very, very, very, very big appetite.

Here’s the handy printable. I hope you all had a wonderful weekend!

 

Recipe

Leftover Easter Sandwich

Prep Time:
15 Minutes
Cook Time:
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
8
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 12 whole Hard Boiled Eggs
  • 1/2 cup Mayonnaise
  • 3 Tablespoons Grainy Dijon Mustard
  • Salt And Pepper, to taste
  • Several Dashes Worcestershire Sauce
  • Leftover Baked Ham, Sliced
  • Kaiser Rolls Or Other Bread
  • Extra Mayonnaise And Dijon, For Spreading
  • Swiss Cheese Or Other Cheese Slices
  • Thinly Sliced Red Onion
  • Avocado Slices
  • Sliced Tomatoes
  • Lettuce, Spinach, Or Arugula

Preparation Instructions

Make egg salad by chopping the hard boiled eggs and mixing in a bowl with mayonnaise, Dijon, salt and pepper, Worcestershire (and you can also add chopped pickles, hot sauce, etc.) Taste and adjust seasonings.

Halve the rolls and spread one half with Dijon, the other half with mayonnaise. Sprinkle the mayonnaise-spread half with salt and pepper. Lay cheese and ham on the mustard half; lay avocado, onion slices, tomato slices, egg salad, and lettuce on the other half.

Bring the two halves together and chow down!

Variation: Add bacon! Yes, I said it.

Posted by Ree on April 1 2013

item.title: Classic Movie Quiz Answers and Winners
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: What a quiz! Before I post the answers and winners, here are a few stats: * 7,692 people took the quiz. * 752 players scored 100%. * The question most people (94%) got right was…#3! * The question most people got wrong (only 41% got it right!) was…#21. (This was the Fredo question.) Here are the answers and winners!   ANSWERS Q.3 Where does “It’s a Wonderful Life” take place? Bedford Hills ***Bedford Falls Bedford…
item.content:encoded:
What a quiz! Before I post the answers and winners, here are a few stats:

* 7,692 people took the quiz.
* 752 players scored 100%.
* The question most people (94%) got right was…#3!
* The question most people got wrong (only 41% got it right!) was…#21. (This was the Fredo question.)

Here are the answers and winners!

 

ANSWERS

Q.3
Where does “It’s a Wonderful Life” take place?

Bedford Hills
***Bedford Falls
Bedford Lake
Bedford City

 
 
 
Q.4
In “The Godfather,” who was murdered in the causeway?

Luca Brasi
Moe Greene
***Sonny
Paulie

 
 
 
Q.5
Where did Princess Leia hide the stolen plans for the Death Star?

In C-3PO
In a pocket in the hem of her white gown
In the Millennium Falcon
***In R2-D2

 
 
 
Q.6
In which of the following films did Robert Duvall NOT appear?

To Kill a Mockingbird
The Godfather
Tender Mercies
***One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest

 
 
 
Q.7
Where did Benjamin’s love interest Elaine go to college?

USC
***Berkeley
UCLA
Stanford

 
 
 
Q.8
Who was Scarlett O’Hara’s second husband?

***Frank Kennedy
Rhett Butler
Ashley Wilkes
Charles Hamilton

 
 
 
Q.9
“12 cabins, 12 vacancies.”

***Psycho
Vertigo
North by Northwest
Ben-Hur

 
 
 
Q.10
In “Shawshank Redemption,” what does Andy request in his weekly letters to the state?

Better medical care in the prison
Better food in the prison
***A library in the prison
A workout facility in the prison

 
 
 
Q.11
Which of the following movies was NOT set during World War II?

Midway
Casablanca
***Apocalypse Now
Patton

 
 
 
Q.12
In “The Wizard of Oz,” Tin Man wished for a brain.

True
***False

 
 
 
Q.13
On what national memorial did Cary Grant end up in “North by Northwest?”

Washington Monument
***Mount Rushmore
Grant’s Tomb
Lincoln Memorial

 
 
 
Q.14
What does E.T. tell Elliot when he leaves Earth?

“E.T. phone home.”
“Me like Reeses Pieces.”
***”I’ll be right here.”
“I’ll be right back.”

 
 
 
Q.15
What are the names of the rival gangs in “West Side Story?”

Sharks and Tigers
Jets and Tigers
***Sharks and Jets
Lions and Panthers

 
 
 
Q.16
Where was Forest Gump shot in Vietnam?

The pinkie toe
The ear lobe
***The bottom
The knee

 
 
 
Q.17
“Love means never having to say you’re sorry.”

When Harry Met Sally
***Love Story
Terms of Endearment
The Champ

 
 
 
Q.18
I coulda been a contender!

A Streetcar Named Desire
Sunset Boulevard
***On the Waterfront
Rebel Without a Cause

 
 
 
Q.19
“Snakes. Why’d it have to be snakes?”

***Raiders of the Lost Ark
Star Wars
Anaconda
Snakes on a Plane

 
 
 
Q.20
“Plastics.”

Tootsie
The Running Man
Midnight Cowboy
***The Graduate

 
 
 
Q.21
“Fredo, you’re my older brother, and I love you. But don’t ever take sides with anyone against the family again. Ever.”

***The Godfather
The Godfather, Part II
The Godfather, Part III

(Michael says this to Fredo in Las Vegas in Godfather I. He has just offered to buy the casino from Moe Greene, and Fredo sticks up for Moe’s position over Michael’s.)

 
 
 
Q.22
“Because they stand on a wall. And they say, ‘Nothing’s gonna hurt you tonight; not on my watch.’”

Platoon
***A Few Good Men
The Deer Hunter
Crimson Tide

 

WINNERS

The first place winner is…Pamela J!
The second place winner is…Gabrielle S.
The third place winner is…Ash B.

Congrats, winners! Contact prizes@thepioneerwoman.com to claim your prizes.

Before we start, note that I chose movies based on those I consider to be “classics,” which doesn’t always necessarily translate to “old movie.” There’s quite a mix in here! To take the quiz, answer the questions below. 1. FIRST PLACE: The first person to correctly answer all questions wins: This beautiful blue KitchenAid mixer! No, it doesn’t have anything to do with movies…but life doesn’t always have…
item.content:encoded:
Time for the Big Classic Movie Quiz! Before we start, note that I chose movies based on those I consider to be “classics,” which doesn’t always necessarily translate to “old movie.” There’s quite a mix in here!

To take the quiz, answer the questions below.

1. FIRST PLACE: The first person to correctly answer all questions wins:

This beautiful blue KitchenAid mixer!

No, it doesn’t have anything to do with movies…but life doesn’t always have to make sense! Ha.

2. SECOND PLACE: One randomly selected player from among the first 25 players to score 100% will receive a second place prize: a $200 Amazon.com gift card.

3. THIRD PLACE: A third place winner will be randomly chosen among all contestants who score 100% and will win a $100 Amazon.com gift card.

Answers and winners will be revealed Sunday night.

Feel free to shout out your scores in the Comments!

 

Take Our Survey!

item.title: How to determine the level to begin homeschooling my son?
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.description: Community Question is a category inspired by you. Here and there readers write in with questions that are better served by the varied, experiential knowledge of those who read and contribute in the comments. Have a question for the community? Email it to Heather. *********************************************** The following question is from Holly J. “Hello! My husband and I decided to start homeschooling our oldest son who is about to be 6. He is currently attending a…
item.content:encoded:
Community Question is a category inspired by you. Here and there readers write in with questions that are better served by the varied, experiential knowledge of those who read and contribute in the comments. Have a question for the community? Email it to Heather.

***********************************************

The following question is from Holly J.

“Hello! My husband and I decided to start homeschooling our oldest son who is about to be 6. He is currently attending a private Christian school that uses A Beka. While we like the school, and have no problem with them per se, we feel that he is not challenged enough. I should also add that my son is advanced, learning to read in just 2 months at age 4, and is a self-motivated learner. Up until this point we have really only introduced subjects to him (math, science, the dinosaurs, etc…), and then let him loose with a book.

Right now I’m unsure how to know what level to start homeschooling him. His teacher sends home reading assignments for a 2nd or 3rd grader, and his math is at a 1st grade level.

Do you have any suggestions for Holly regarding what grade/level to start homeschooling her son?

item.title: The Windows Have Landed
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: The new windows have been coming in in batches of ten, and it’s so exciting to watch them go in. You can see in this photo that the run of windows along the right side of the building have been replaced. The ones on the side of the building facing us…well, not so much. But soon.       These’ll be coming next, and I can’t wait to see ‘em. I love this part of…
item.content:encoded:
The new windows have been coming in in batches of ten, and it’s so exciting to watch them go in. You can see in this photo that the run of windows along the right side of the building have been replaced. The ones on the side of the building facing us…well, not so much.

But soon.

 
 
 
These’ll be coming next, and I can’t wait to see ‘em. I love this part of the building.

 
 
 
Here’s the view from Main Street.

 
 
 
Brent was hard at work sealing the windows yesterday.

 
 
 
These were the windows in the back of the building in February.

 
 
 
This is the view from the alley now. We started back there and are working our way around. The windows get taken out and hauled to Missouri in groups of ten…then come back some time later.

 
 
 
As I explained here, we aren’t replacing with brand new windows; we’re having the old ones redone. Once they make it back here, Terry’s crew is wrapping the woodwork in metal to make them ultra-durable.

 
 
 
Here’s a slightly closer look (I’ll try to get some process shots of the guys covering the windows when the next batch comes in.) Most of the frame is wrapped in metal; the only thing they’re having to paint is the sash around the glass.

That’ll save us a lot of maintenance down the line.

 
 
 
This is the west side of the building. There’ll be lots to do here: Windows, of course, but then we’ll remove the huge awning (it’s on its last leg), blast the green paint off the brick, and redo the fronts of the two spaces.

And take a nap every now and then.

 
 
 
It’s fun to see the windows on the outside…but it’s even better to see how it transforms the inside. This is the upstairs space a year or so ago.

 
 
 
And here it is with the new windwos.

 
 
 
This room hasn’t seen this much light in…well, 40 years? 50 years? More?

 
 
 
And in this corner of the other room next door…

 
 
 
Let there be light!

In other news, a wall is coming down next week. I’ll share all the dusty details then.

Love,
P-Widdy

item.title: Good Friday Morning
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: We had a busy day in the big city yesterday that involved a soccer game, an action movie, and Easter dress shopping with two teenage girls over 5’11″. Which one of these three things do you think ended in tears?     Anyway, we were all ready for a peaceful Good Friday on the ranch today.       Peaceful, of course, doesn’t necessarily mean there isn’t work to do.       There are…
item.content:encoded:
We had a busy day in the big city yesterday that involved a soccer game, an action movie, and Easter dress shopping with two teenage girls over 5’11″.

Which one of these three things do you think ended in tears?

 
 
Anyway, we were all ready for a peaceful Good Friday on the ranch today.

 
 
 
Peaceful, of course, doesn’t necessarily mean there isn’t work to do.

 
 
 
There are some cattle to gather this morning.

 
 
 
The animals on the ranch don’t observe holidays.

 
 
 
Marlboro Man observes holidays. After the animals are taken care of.

 
 
 
So after the cattle are gathered…

 
 
 
And the work is done for the day…

 
 
 
We’re going to settle in and enjoy the rest of our day together.

 
 
 
Maybe make some Hot Cross Buns.

 
 
 
Maybe boil the eggs for dyeing tomorrow.

 
 
 
Maybe go up against mom in a round or two of Just Dance 3.

She beat everyone last time. Creamed ‘em, actually.

That mom. She’s got moves like no other!

 
 
 
“Emphasis on ‘like no other.’”

Ahem.

Have a very blessed Good Friday, friends.

Lots of love,
P-Dub

item.title: How, or do you, shape what you will teach?
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.description: By Heather Sanders. Yesterday, I spent an entire morning and early afternoon catching up with my closest friend and confidante, Cindy. Together we serve on the board of our local homeschool cooperative, plan and attend field trips, scrutinize and select curriculum and discuss our daily homeschooling challenges. She is a certified teacher and a phenomenal listener, and I am certifiably annoying, and an avid talker, so we balance beautifully. Outside of my family, she is…
item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders.

Yesterday, I spent an entire morning and early afternoon catching up with my closest friend and confidante, Cindy. Together we serve on the board of our local homeschool cooperative, plan and attend field trips, scrutinize and select curriculum and discuss our daily homeschooling challenges. She is a certified teacher and a phenomenal listener, and I am certifiably annoying, and an avid talker, so we balance beautifully.

Outside of my family, she is probably my biggest fan, but recently confessed she does not actually read my posts, “But I always look at the pictures”, she emphatically proclaimed. I quickly forgave her because I know that by the time I muster the words to post she has heard them at least a half-dozen times, tossed out in far too many theoretical arguments for her to have to read them again. God bless her because yesterday’s conversation was no different.

After reading all the comments about homeschooling styles in last week’s post, I want to talk about my favorite new brain drain, Unschooling, or rather, how, or if, parents should play a role in shaping what they teach, and their children learn.

I am in the process of working through my own thoughts regarding the whole Structured Homeschooling versus Unschooling conundrum. I don’t think it is a black and white issue; it appears that, just as with homeschooling, there are all different shades of grey between the two.

Here are the questions I’m knocking around in my head this week. Feel free to respond to any one of them, or all of them, in the comments below.

1. Is structure necessary for the early elementary years?

It was my experience that all three of my children loved having books read to them from an early age. Jeff and I took turns reading their favorite stories over and over until they could recite them from memory while running their pudgy little fingers under the words across the page.

While I remember pointing out letter names and sounds, the basic 3-letter words seemed to progress naturally; however, when the kids advanced to sight words there was considerably more work involved for all of us. I made up games and activities to help memorize the words, and soon we began stringing words together in sentences. At times, they were frustrated or bored, but then they would have what I call “break through moments”, when they would shine with pride at what they just achieved or understood.

The same thing was true with Math. In the beginning, it was easy to show them that when they had one block, and added one more, then they had two blocks. As the concepts built on each other, so have the challenges.

While I understand that the philosophy behind Unschooling is to set the stage for natural learning to thrive, I am not certain most kids would decide to memorize sight words in Kindergarten, or later on, to memorize their multiplication tables. Perhaps Unschooled parents lean on some subjects more than others? Most Unschooling families I am exposed to do not purchase a set curriculum. Is the idea to surround one’s children with more interest led subject matter that points to reading, writing and math? If there is not a set structure I am curious what learning looks like, and how parents can be certain the foundation is laid.

2. Is testing necessary at any point?

Until we joined our local homeschool cooperative, I never formally tested my children or applied grades on anything they learned. I was fully aware of their level of learning as we worked together. If I felt a concept was dropped, we reviewed back over it until it was clear.

In the back of my head, I figured I would be forced to grade once they reached their high school years in order to build an honest transcript, and I left it at that.

I’m not sure that is relevant to Unschooling, but it certainly is a radical off-shoot from the Structured Homeschooling approach.

It wasn’t that testing scared me–I just didn’t find it necessary. Some people say that testing is just a means to stroke parent egos, as opposed to accessing true knowledge and understanding. I schooled my children at home, and there was not a need to compare my children to others. I simply focused on teaching them, and as they grew in maturity, I showed them how to find the resources they needed to learn on their own.

Now that my older daughter is finishing up her Sophomore year, we have an established transcript with grades. With all the research about testing, it becomes more and more obvious that test grades are not necessarily the Holy Grail of true understanding or intelligence. So, why do we test and keep grades?

I keep them out of fear of somehow limiting her potential future. The world is changing, and Emelie is not at all interested in pursuing academia through a 4-year university, but I still keep those high school grades just in case. Maybe mine will be the last generation that frets over their children’s test scores and transcripts.

3. If parents don’t set expectations for learning, will kids grow to respect and meet the expectations of others?

Who we become as adults is directly affected by the family culture we grew up in. I realize that there are exceptions to every rule, but for the most part, there are many things that carry through from one generation to the next. Though our very nature is ingrained, there are aspects of how we are nurtured in our childhood that play out in how we relate to others in our adult life, specifically others who are in a position of authority over us.

If as parents, we do not set expectations for learning for our children, and if they get to decide what they want to learn and when they want to learn it, is there a valid argument that says they will have difficulty meeting the expectations of future bosses?

On one hand, I want to say that the freedom to choose one’s own learning path is unrelated to whether or not we will be able to submit to another’s expectations in the future. Perhaps the single act of a parent respecting a child’s right to their own learning leaves the child emotionally stable enough not to cultivate a spirit of rebellion that would cause them to rebuff the expectations of a supervisor later on in life.

Then again, if we never require our children to meet any standard that they don’t set for themselves, will they become overly egocentric, believing the world revolves around them? Do we inadvertently set them up for failure by freeing them from failure in the early years?

At this point, it might be readily obvious why Cindy is such a good friend for me. She lends an ear to all my mind’s inner ramblings, quietly taking them in and processing them as I toss more and more her way.

I know one thing, if I had been Unschooled, I would need a strong visionary to guide me out of the murky bog because I get fixated with all the details. I used to believe Unschooling was taking the easy way out – I was wrong. It is much easier to follow the old school rules of engagement. We have to ask ourselves whether or not those rules are the most effective approach for today’s world.

Now it’s your turn. How, or do you, shape what you teach your children?

 

OMSH/Heather L. Sanders is a wife, mother and friend. She is also a Homeschooling Blogger and Writer. Balance is the challenge she rises to each and every morning.

item.title: Pretty, Yummy Fruit Salad
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: I think you’ll love this colorful, pretty fruit salad, which is drizzled with a lovely orange-vanilla syrup, which glosses it up and makes it visually irresistible, which makes you want to stand over the bowl and slurp up every single bite, which won’t leave any for your brunch guests. So logic would probably tell you not not to make it. But I think you should go ahead and chance it! It’s that good. Slightly citrusy,…
item.content:encoded:
I think you’ll love this colorful, pretty fruit salad, which is drizzled with a lovely orange-vanilla syrup, which glosses it up and makes it visually irresistible, which makes you want to stand over the bowl and slurp up every single bite, which won’t leave any for your brunch guests.

So logic would probably tell you not not to make it.

But I think you should go ahead and chance it! It’s that good. Slightly citrusy, nice and sweet, with a little hint of vanilla lusciousness. So simple to make, and you can use any fruit you want—melon chunks, orange pieces, apples, pears…the works. And it’s perfect not just for Easter brunch, but for baby or wedding showers, special lunches…or just a weekday that calls for a beautiful bowl of color.

Here’s how to make it, Maynard!

Sorry I called you Maynard again.

Next year I’ll give it up for Lent. Promise.

 
Add sugar and water to a small saucepan…

 
 
 
Then zest a juicy orange and add the zest to the pan…

 
 
 
Then cut the orange in half…

 
 
 
And squeeze the juice into the pan.

 
 
 
Slice two vanilla beans in half…

 
 
 
Then scrape out the caviar inside…

 
 
 
And add it to the saucepan. Yum!

(Note: You can just add 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract if you don’t have vanilla beans. Still delicious!)

 
 
 
Stir it around and bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer the syrup for a good 15-20 minutes, until it’s thickened a bit. After that, put the pan in the fridge to cool the syrup completely (or transfer the syrup into a little pitcher or bowl.) You want the syrup to be cold when you pour it on the fruit.

(You can make this the night before you need it!)

 
 
 
When you’re ready to assemble the fruit salad, wash all the fruit you want to use. Anything colorful and gorgeous-looking will do.

 
 
 
I did a bunch of strawberries…

 
 
 
And threw them into a big bowl.

 
 
 
Then halved a bunch of red grapes…

 
 
 
And threw them in with the strawberries.

 
 
 
Then did the same with green grapes, because they matched the bowl. And this is very important. Not really.

 
 
 
Blueberries sounded good, too!

 
 
 
Pour half of the cold syrup over the top…

 
 
 
Then toss the fruit gently to coat it in the rest of the syrup as you drizzle it in. You can’t really see it in the photos, but the tiny flecks of vanilla bean really make this look special.

 
 
 
Simply gorgeous!

 
 
 
But fresh mint makes it…

 
 
 
Well, simply gorgeous-er.

Hope you’re having a wonderful Holy Week, guys.

Here’s the handy dandy printable:

Recipe

Fruit Salad

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
20 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1 cup Sugar
  • 1 cup Water
  • Juice Of 1 Orange
  • Zest Of 1 Orange
  • 2 whole Vanilla Beans, Caviar Scraped Out (or 2 Teaspoons Vanilla Extract)
  • 4 pints Strawberries, Hulled And Halved
  • 2 pints Blueberries
  • 2 cups Red Grapes, Halved
  • 2 cups Green Grapes, Havled
  • Mint Leaves

Preparation Instructions

Place the sugar, water, orange juice and orange zest into a small saucepan and stir to combine. Bring to a boil, then turn the heat to low and simmer for 15-20 to thicken slightly. Set aside to cool, then store in the fridge until cold.

Mix together all the fruit in a large bowl and pour the syrup over the top, tossing gently. Garnish with mint leaves and serve.

Posted by Ree on March 28 2013

item.title: The Jeans I Like
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: I posted this photo on Confessions last week, and I got a few questions about what jeans I was wearing.   They’re “Skinny Kick” jeans from American Eagle, and I love them. They have a nice slim fit without being ridiculously tight and “skinny jean” skinny. (I burned out on skinny jeans months and months ago because they made me feel bad about myself. Ha.) These are more of a “real world” skinny jean with…
item.content:encoded:
I posted this photo on Confessions last week, and I got a few questions about what jeans I was wearing.

 
They’re “Skinny Kick” jeans from American Eagle, and I love them. They have a nice slim fit without being ridiculously tight and “skinny jean” skinny. (I burned out on skinny jeans months and months ago because they made me feel bad about myself. Ha.) These are more of a “real world” skinny jean with a little bit of an everyday style. (Please note: The model in this particular photo is probably six sizes smaller than me. But you can get a sense of the style of the jeans. The leg is slightly more flared at the bottom than this pic shows.)

Here are the pros and cons of Skinny Kicks.

PROS

* They have a nice stretch/give to them.

* They have a nice slightly flared leg without being crazy-flared or hippie looking. I can wear boots under the legs or I can wear flats. Both work.

* They’re somewhat slim through the hips and thighs but not tight.

* I love all three washes (the antique is my favorite, and it’s also the least expensive of the three.)

CONS

* They are just a leeeeeetle bit low-waisted. Definitely not in the crazy category of low-waisted—you know, the category that only .008% of the population can pull off. But if I’ve chowed down right before I wear them or haven’t done Pilates for a week, I always wish they had an extra inch or so. Still they’re not bad—I wear them all the time. I just have to stand up a little straighter when I wear them to keep the muffin top at bay.

* The dark blue wash (“Black Rock”) is so saturated, it does slightly rub off here and there. I only noticed it because when I first got a couple of pairs and wore them, I’d see a little bit of a dark blue hue to my fingertips. At first I thought I was dying. Then I realized it was the jeans.

Pros and cons weighed and analyzed, my verdict is that I love these jeans. I’ll keep wearing them for a long time!

Skinny Kick Jeans at American Eagle

Love,
P-Dub

Not an advertisement. Just sharing the jeans I like, man.

item.title: Glazed Easter Ham
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Easter is coming, the goose is getting fat! Wait. That’s Christmas. And Christmas isn’t coming. At least not for 272 more days. Okay, now that I’ve both confused and depressed everyone: Here’s the recipe for the yummy glazed ham I made on my show last Saturday—the same ham I’ll be making this Sunday for Easter brunch. It’s totally easy, exceedingly delicious, and results in a purty and glossy ham that’ll make your guests say “Oooooooh!”…
item.content:encoded:
Easter is coming, the goose is getting fat!

Wait. That’s Christmas.

And Christmas isn’t coming. At least not for 272 more days.

Okay, now that I’ve both confused and depressed everyone: Here’s the recipe for the yummy glazed ham I made on my show last Saturday—the same ham I’ll be making this Sunday for Easter brunch. It’s totally easy, exceedingly delicious, and results in a purty and glossy ham that’ll make your guests say “Oooooooh!” with wide, expectant eyes and, hopefully, hearty appetites because this ham could feed an army.

Here’s how I made it.

 
Get a big honkin’ bone-in ham. Fully cooked.

 
 
 
Use a really sharp knife to score a diamond pattern all over the surface of the ham: First cut lines in one direction…

 
 
 
Then cut in the other direction.

 
 
 
Grab a handful of cloves and poke them into the center of each diamond…

 
 
 
And keep going until the whole surface is dotted. I do this for looks more than flavor: I just think it looks lovely and traditional when it’s all done baking.

 
 
 
Cover the ham with foil, then put it into the oven to warm it up. I do 325 for at least 2 to 2 1/2 hours, but I’d say just look at the instructions on the package and follow those. Some hams say to go 3 to 4 hours, some at a lower temperature. The whole goal here is just to heat the ham slowly…and it takes awhile to do that.

 
 
 
While the ham is in the oven, you can make the glaze: Throw 3 cups of brown sugar into a saucepan…

 
 
 
Along with 1/2 cup of grainy, spicy mustard for a nice tang…

 
 
 
3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar for a little bite…

 
 
 
And the star of the show!

 
 
 
A whole can of Dr Pepper.

You can use Coke. Heck, you could probably even use root beer. But please, for the love of all things good and caramelized, do not use diet pop.

(It’s the sugar we’re after here.)

Amen.

 
 
 
Bring this mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat…

 
 
 
And simmer it for a good 15-20 minutes until it’s gotten darker and thicker.

 
 
 
After the ham has cooked for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, brush the surface with some of the glaze. Then pop it back into the oven, uncovered, for another 20 minutes or so.

 
 
 
Pull it out and brush on more glaze, then pop it back in the oven.

 
 
 
Then pull it out and brush on more glaze! Keep doing this until the ham is fully heated and the glaze is really gorgeous and glossy.

Note: On my Food Network episode last weekend, I only glazed it once because I had been at church and didn’t want to add too much more time before we ate. It was still totally delicious, but glazing the ham 2 or 3 (or 4) times really results in more of a masterpiece in terms of gorgeous surface.

 
 
 
Mmmm. Easter feast!

 
 
 
Enjoy, guys. This ham’ll take you far in life.

Here’s the handy printable!

Recipe

Glazed Easter Ham

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
3 Hours
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
18
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1 whole Fully Cooked Bone-in Ham (15-18 Pounds)
  • Whole Cloves
  • 3 cups Brown Sugar
  • 1/2 cup Spicy Brown Mustard
  • 1 can Dr Pepper Or Coke
  • 3 Tablespoons Apple Cider Vinegar

Preparation Instructions

Preheat the oven to 325 F.

Score the surface of the ham in a diamond pattern about 1/8-inch deep. Place cloves in the middle of each diamond. Place the ham in a large roasting pan with a rack, tent it with foil, and bake for 2 to 2/12 hours---or longer, depending on the package directions. (Some hams may require 3 to 3 1/2 hours at a lower temp; just check the package.)

Heat the brown sugar, mustard, vinegar and soda in a small saucepan until bubbly. Cook until reduced and a bit thicker, about 15 minutes.

After about 2 hours of baking time, remove the foil and brush the glaze on the ham in 20 minutes intervals (put the ham back in the oven, uncovered, in between) until it's nice and glossy. Remove from the oven and allow to rest 15-20 minutes before carving.

Posted by Ree on March 27 2013

item.title: Last Day
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: First of all…   Luke’s photo is the winner of the Instagram contest!       Congratulations, Luke.       Matt, your horse photo was awesome. You were a very worthy opponent!       So was your grill photo, Mike! I’ll stop shouting now! Sheesh, Ree!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Sorry. Anyway, the guys will all be hightailing it back to England soon. I’ll miss the ol’ chaps. But I’m going to be happy not to wear…
item.content:encoded:
First of all…

 
Luke’s photo is the winner of the Instagram contest!

 
 
 
Congratulations, Luke.

 
 
 
Matt, your horse photo was awesome. You were a very worthy opponent!

 
 
 
So was your grill photo, Mike!

I’ll stop shouting now!

Sheesh, Ree!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Sorry.

Anyway, the guys will all be hightailing it back to England soon.

I’ll miss the ol’ chaps.

But I’m going to be happy not to wear a mic for awhile. I’d like to go to the bathroom without unplugging first.

Sometimes I get stage fright.

You don’t want to know any more than that.

 
 
 
Yesterday I shot an entire show in one day, which is unusual. Typically, episodes take 1 1/2 to 2 days to shoot, but this one was basically shoot-as-it-happens. It was a freezer meal theme: I filled the freezer with lots of yummy food for busy days in my house, which is every day, and man, am I excited to have all this grub.

*Burp*

 
 
 
Here, Mike is rigging the freezer door so it won’t keep hitting me on the bottom as I stand and describe some of the things I’d stocked the freezer with.

It was getting a little embarrassing.

“This is a great freezer casserole. Really great flavor…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“One thing I like to do is store grilled chicken breasts in airtight bags…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“This is one of my favorite freezer soups. To make it, you…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

This is just another behind-the-scenes wrinkle you never think about when you watch cooking shows on TV: Freezer doors hitting the person on the bottom every time they try to talk.

It’s one of those things no one ever talks about.

 
 
This is my precious firstborn son. He makes my heart leap. I’ve been making him and his brother come hang out in my dressing room so I can listen to them talk about football and accuse them of eating all my snacks.

Man, can they polish off some snacks. Like, whole packages. Gone. Poof. As if the snacks ever existed.

 
 
 
I make Charlie come hang out in my dressing room, too.

 
 
 
It’s nice to walk in there and get a nice whiff of hound funk anytime I need a little pick-me-up.

Really keeps me going.

Or…not.

Have a happy Tuesday, everyone!

item.title: Eggs in Hash Brown Nests
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: These are the perfect little side dish for Easter Brunch: Tender-but-crispy potato nests with a luscious baked egg in the middle. They go perfectly with ham for a more substantial brunch, or they’re great for a casual breakfast with a piece of bacon. Or two. Or three. Or nineteen. I will say, when I first decided to try these out, I was excited. I’d seen different iterations of the little cutie-pies and I figured they’d…
item.content:encoded:
These are the perfect little side dish for Easter Brunch: Tender-but-crispy potato nests with a luscious baked egg in the middle. They go perfectly with ham for a more substantial brunch, or they’re great for a casual breakfast with a piece of bacon. Or two. Or three. Or nineteen.

I will say, when I first decided to try these out, I was excited. I’d seen different iterations of the little cutie-pies and I figured they’d be a piece of cake to whip up. But in fact, I had to go through quite a bit of trial and error before I cracked the dang code. And by the time I figured it all out, I think I’d shaved a good seven months off of my life expectancy.

I started off trying frozen hash brown potatoes, which I initially assumed would work fine. But they wound up being way, way too dry: During the initial baking of the nest, they shriveled to almost nothing, and after the egg baked inside the nests, the hash browns turned a very strange consistency—and there was hardly any potato flavor at all. Super dry, super weird.

Frozen Hash Browns = A no-go for this recipe. Like, totally.

After giving up on the frozen potatoes, I wound up fiddling with fresh potatoes in a couple of different ways: First I tried grating them from a raw state, which didn’t work at all. Too mushy. Didn’t crisp up. Produced angst. Made me crazy.

Finally, the best result came from grating almost-fully-baked potatoes: The consistency was perfect and the potato flavor was fabulous.

Then I slept for a month because I was so exhausted.

It would be a long, long time before I’d be able to trust again.

 
 
Here’s how to make them! Start by baking a few potatoes. I scrubbed the potatoes, then baked them until they were not quite tender enough to eat: Soft, but with the tiniest bit of bite left. This will make them easier to grate, and will also allow more room for baking later.

 
 
 
I let them cool almost completely (you could bake the potatoes Saturday night and keep them in the fridge), then peeled them with a paring knife.

 
 
 
Grate all the potatoes, using the largest grating size. As you grate them, if you hear just a tiny bit of “crunch” signifying that the potato isn’t fully cooked, that’s just fine, Maynard.

Sorry I called you Maynard.

Next, season the potatoes generously with salt and pepper: Just toss them around with your hands as you sprinkle.

 
 
 
Spray a muffin pan lightly with a little cooking spray…

 
 
 
Then drop a small amount (a little less than 1/4 cup) into each muffin cup.

 
 
 
Use your fingers to lightly press the center so that the potatoes spill over the top a bit. They’ll shrink when they bake, so don’t be afraid to really spill over the top.

 
 
 
Sprinkle on a tiny bit more salt and pepper…

 
 
 
Then give the tops just a very light spray again.

 
 
 
Bake them for about 20-25 minutes (note the increased oven temp in printable recipe below) until they’re golden brown. Keep an eye on them so the ends of the potato shreds don’t burn.

You can see how much the potatoes shrink up!

 
 
 
Now, I let the nests cool a bit (you can even bake them off an hour or two ahead of time and let them totally cool) before cracking in the eggs.

 
 
 
Let the eggs bake for 10-15 minutes, until they get to the level of doneness you’re looking for. I still like to have a little softness to the yolks, and mine baked for probably 12 minutes or so.

* Note: Be assured that no matter what, all of your eggs will probably bake a little differently and won’t all look exactly the same on top. Some whites will look perfect, some might look a little funky. Some whites will cover the yolk, some will gloriously reveal the yolk.

But that’s the beauty of these things! They’re rustic.

Ha.

 
 
 
These are great with Easter Ham (I’ll post the recipe here next)! If you feel like you need a little practice before Sunday, you can pare down the amounts and do a practice run with one potato and two or three eggs. The instructions are the same whether you make a big batch or a small one.

These are totally delicious. My family loves them. My brother-in-law Tim likes to douse them with hot sauce. (I have to admit, I do too.)

Here’s the handy printable:

Recipe

Eggs in Hash Brown Nests

Prep Time:
15 Minutes
Cook Time:
1 Hour30 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 6 whole Medium Russet Potatoes (6 To 8)
  • Salt And Pepper, to taste
  • 24 whole Large Eggs
  • Non-stick Cooking Spray

Preparation Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.

Bake the potatoes until almost tender (potatoes should still have a little bite) 45 minutes to 1 hour. Allow to cool, and then peel and grate them. Season well with salt and pepper.

INCREASE OVEN TEMP TO 425 DEGREES.

Spray two muffin pans generously with cooking spray. Scoop 3 to 4 tablespoons of grated potato into each muffin cup. Use your fingers to gently press the sides and bottom in each muffin hole to make a nest (don't press the potatoes firmly against the pan; they should sit lightly in the pan.) Spray again (very lightly!) with cooking spray. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes. Watch and make sure they do not burn. (If they seem like they're not browning, kick up the temp to 450.) Remove when the nests are golden brown.

Allow the nests to cool. Crack an egg into each one. Sprinkle with salt and pepper and bake until the whites are set, about 15 minutes. Don't be concerned if some whites bake differently; no two nests will look alike!

Remove from the muffin pan with a spoon or fork and serve.

Posted by Ree on March 26 2013

item.title: Women of the Frontier
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.category: Book ReviewsContributorsEnglish/LiteratureHistory/GeographyHomeschooling MaterialsOMSHAmerican History Readerspioneer womenWestward Expansionwestward movement
item.description: By Heather Sanders. There are only 6 weeks left in our co-op’s school year, and Kenny has blazed through 19 of the 25 readers purchased or borrowed for his American History course. Now that he is studying the Westward Movement, he and I both realized we failed to collect a single reader about the Americans who felt it was their “Manifest Destiny” to Go West, settling the continent from the Atlantic to Pacific Oceans. Imagine…
item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders.

There are only 6 weeks left in our co-op’s school year, and Kenny has blazed through 19 of the 25 readers purchased or borrowed for his American History course.

Now that he is studying the Westward Movement, he and I both realized we failed to collect a single reader about the Americans who felt it was their “Manifest Destiny” to Go West, settling the continent from the Atlantic to Pacific Oceans.

Imagine my excitement at the timing when Chicago Review Press sent a copy of the newest release in their Women of Action series, Women of the Frontier: 16 Tales of Trailblazing, Homesteaders, Entrepreneurs, and Rabble-Rousers by Brandon Marie Miller.

March is Women’s History Month, and I realize that means I’m a little late on the draw as we are steadfastly heading into April. Still, when I find a good book I like to share it, and this book completely captures the courage of the pioneering women of the mid-1800s.

Kenny couldn’t help but be interested in it after seeing me take it to bed three nights in a row. The first chapter about how Margret Reed survived starvation near Lake Truckee in the Sierra Nevada sucked him in immediately. From missionaries and physicians to naturalists and suffragettes, the stories are taken directly from the “ordinary lives of daughters, sisters, wives, and mothers.”

Miller weaves this collection of abridged biographies, period photos, letters home, and even song lyrics so artfully that I finished wanting to know more about each of their personal lives. Trekking 2,000 miles across a seemingly endless frontier, these 19th century women were hard core, leaving behind friends and family they would likely never see again, for the hope of a better life.

The sufferings endured on the wagon train often did not ease up after arriving at their destination; at that point, the pioneer women learned to meet their challenges, fears and setbacks with perseverance and determination as they worked side-by-side with their husbands to build log cabins or sod houses, work the land, mills, stores, or inns, all while caring for children, pregnancy, and bearing/raising babies.

While some of the women adapted more readily than others, most of their writing reveals their appreciation for the rugged beauty they came to see in the new landscape of their lives.

Targeted for middle school students ages 12 and up, Brandon Marie Miller’s Women of the Frontier: 16 Tales of Trailblazing, Homesteaders, Entrepreneurs, and Rabble-Rousers is a wonderful supplement to any study of American History and the Westward Movement.

Are you a fan of stories from this period? Any Westward Movement reader recommendations for middle school and up?

 

OMSH/Heather L. Sanders is a wife, mother and friend. She is also a Homeschooling Blogger and Writer. Balance is the challenge she rises to each and every morning.

item.title: The Family That Photobombs Together…
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: First: I shared this photo of my youngest child on PW Home & Garden this morning. In that post, I’m featuring the groovy bow tie he’s wearing. But in this post, I’m just showing you the photo because I love it.     I’m showing you this one for the same reason. Wait. Did you hear that? Did you hear that noise? That was my heart going pitter-pat. Boys wearing bow ties will do that…
item.content:encoded:
First: I shared this photo of my youngest child on PW Home & Garden this morning. In that post, I’m featuring the groovy bow tie he’s wearing. But in this post, I’m just showing you the photo because I love it.

 
 
I’m showing you this one for the same reason.

Wait. Did you hear that?

Did you hear that noise?

That was my heart going pitter-pat.

Boys wearing bow ties will do that to a mama.

In other news: I just have a day or so of shooting left, which means I’m about 24 hours away from not showering, not wearing makeup, not drying or styling my hair, and not caring what my fingernails look like.

Get ready, Marlboro Man! You’re gonna love it.

Or not.

 
 
In related news: This is me putting on my ninetieth coat of mascara.

I would like to report, however, that I have been using brown eyeliner instead of black during this shoot. It’s been hard to step away from the Pat Benetar look, but my soul tells me brown makes more logical sense with my red hair and pigmentless skin.

But man, am I caking on that brown eyeliner. I won’t go down without a fight!

 
 
On the food front: Last week I made cookies.

 
 
 
And puh-tay-tuh chips!

 
 
 
And a sandwich that made the ingesters of the sandwiches very happy.

Is ingesters a word? I’m thinking it isn’t.

 
 
 
During the course of the shoots, the boot room at the Lodge has turned into a little bit of a makeshift kitchen/extra prep area. The boots are running out of patience and are getting ready to stage a coup.

“You city slicker sheet pans have exactly one hour to git outta this here town…”

 
 
 
Matt snapped this photo. Bruiser Pookie Sunshine Of My Life loves having the crew here, but he especially loves Matt. Matt has two terriers back in England and he loves on Bruiser every day because he misses his doggies.

Please look at how Bruiser is sitting.

And speaking of Matt: Matt, Luke, and Mike (the camera and lighting guys on the shoot) are friends on Instagram, and they often post photos and comment on one another’s shots. More than once, I have witnessed some ribbing (read: trash-talking) going on about whose Instagram photos are better.

So I asked each of them to send me one of their favorite Instagram photos of the ranch. Then I asked them if they’d mind if I posted them here.

Then I asked them if they’d mind if I turned it into a contest.

They all said fine.

So here they are!

 
Matt.

 
 
Mike.

 
 
Luke.

Here’s the ballot! I’ll post the winner tomorrow.

 

Matt, Mike, or Luke?

 
 
Here, Nicole, Mike, and Olivia are discussing the lighting and setup for the recipe I’m about to shoot.

 
 
 
Here, I’ve taken a few steps closer and Mike and Olivia are trying to pretend I’m not there.

 
 
 
I love Olivia’s smile!

 
 
 
The other day, Marlboro Man, the kids, and Josh came up for lunch and I tried to get a shot of my beloved. It’s difficult to do these days, because my two teenage daughters are going through a phase wherein they believe photobombing is the most hilarious thing in the world.

Just keep your eye on that tall kid in the background.

 
 
 
See?

 
 
 
Photobombing is kind of funny.

But I think it’s even funnier when the perpetrator gets caught.

 
 
Nobody photobombs a cowboy and gets away with it.

 
 
 
Not even the cowboy’s own daughter.

 
 
 
The family that photobombs together stays together.

At least I think that’s how the saying goes.

item.title: Krispy Easter Eggs
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Imagine the Easter Bunny laying an egg. Wait. That’s not anatomically possible. And anyway, the Easter Bunny is a boy, right? It’s even more impossible than I thought! Okay, let’s start this whole thing over. Imagine that the Easter Bunny’s wife is a chicken, and imagine her laying an egg. These sweet, crispy eggs with a fun candy surprise inside would be what came out! Wait. I don’t think that’s possible either. Sheesh. Leave it…
item.content:encoded:
Imagine the Easter Bunny laying an egg.

Wait. That’s not anatomically possible.

And anyway, the Easter Bunny is a boy, right? It’s even more impossible than I thought!

Okay, let’s start this whole thing over. Imagine that the Easter Bunny’s wife is a chicken, and imagine her laying an egg. These sweet, crispy eggs with a fun candy surprise inside would be what came out!

Wait. I don’t think that’s possible either.

Sheesh. Leave it to me to take something as innocent as an Easter treat and turn it into something disturbing. Please don’t let me spoil this special time for you.

Haunting visuals aside, these adorable little ovoid (vocabulary word alert!) wonders are nothing more than Rice Kripie Treats that have been thrown into a wacky-looking Easter egg machine and, minutes later, come out the other end looking like Easter eggs. They’re super easy and fun to make with kids. The perfect Easter treat!

 
 
 
Add the butter to a pot or large saucepan and melt it over medium heat.

 
 
 
Throw in a bag of mini-marshmallows…

 
 
 
And stir it until the marshmallows are melty and sinful.

 
 
 
Throw in 6 cups of Rice Krispies…

 
 
 
And stir it around gently until it’s all sticky and gooey and combined.

 
 
 
Next, lightly spray the inside of a plastic Easter egg with cooking spray.

You know. Those plastic Easter eggs? The ones you think are taking over your house one minute, then the next minute, when you actually need them to photograph a recipe, you can’t find one to save your life so you drive over to your sister-in-law’s house and borrow hers?

Yes, those plastic Easter eggs.

 
 
 
Stuff one half with the Rice Krispie mixture, then press a chocolate egg into the center. (The official Rice Krispie recipe calls for hollowing out a well and placing small candies in the center, but my motto is “Go Big Chocolate Easter Egg or Go Home.”)

 
 
 
Fill the other half of the egg with more cereal mixture, then press the two halves together until they’re totally closed. The egg should be full enough to meet with a little resistance as you close the egg, but not so full that you feel like you’re crushing the life out of the cereal.

 
 
 
A few seconds later, gently pull the egg out of…well, the egg! I found that the longer you let them sit in the plastic eggs, the harder it was to get out.

 
 
 
Sprinkle them with different springy colors of sprinkles, and place them in an egg holder to let them set.

 
 
 
Let the kids do this part!

Just have a broom nearby.

 
 
 
Lovely and adorable.

Recipe

Krispy Easter Eggs

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
5 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 4 Tablespoons Butter
  • 1 package (10 Ounces) Mini Marshmallows
  • 6 cups Rice Krispies
  • Assorted Sprinkles
  • Small Chocolate Easter Eggs
  • Plastic Easter Eggs

Preparation Instructions

In a large saucepan, melt butter over low heat. Add marshmallows and stir until melted. Remove from heat, then add rice cereal and stir until well coated.

Lightly spray interior of the plastic eggs with non-stick cooking spray. If mixture is too sticky, you can also spray your hands. Fill both sides of the plastic egg with rice cereal mixture, slightly over-filling one side. Press chocolate egg in the center on one side of the egg, then close the plastic egg to shape it. (It should be full enough to meet with a little resistance as you close it.) Gently release the rice cereal egg from the mold, decorate with your choice of sprinkles and set aside in egg crate until set.

Posted by Ree on March 25 2013

item.title: Coolest Bow Ties Ever
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Well, I think these are pretty groovy.       Are you ready?       They’re wooden bow ties.       They’re handmade by two guys (get it?) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.       They use a variety of woods, each one with its own unique grain, and then apply one of a number of patterns to the surface: zig-zag, plaid, etc.       The pics don’t do these justice. They’re truly…
item.content:encoded:
Well, I think these are pretty groovy.

 
 
 
Are you ready?

 
 
 
They’re wooden bow ties.

 
 
 
They’re handmade by two guys (get it?) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

 
 
 
They use a variety of woods, each one with its own unique grain, and then apply one of a number of patterns to the surface: zig-zag, plaid, etc.

 
 
 
The pics don’t do these justice. They’re truly awesome.

 
 
 
My baby wants to wear one to church on Easter Sunday.

(I’ll encourage him to leave my reading glasses at home.)

 
 
 
I just love these things. Really slick, really sleek, a little bit different, and they’re handmade with love.

 
 
 
The bow ties come in Large…

 
 
 
Or Medium.

 
 
 
And the elastic band fastens with a simple hook. Easy!

And here’s the cool thing: On the website, you can either choose from the bow ties in stock OR you can create a custom bow tie by choosing the wood you want, the etched pattern you want, and the fabric/pattern you want in the center. (I love the plaids.) So much fun!

Here’s the website:

Two Guys Bow Ties

Great Father’s Day or birthday gift for the sharp dresser (or dressers) in your life!

Not an advertisement. Just sharing these awesome bow ties from some local craftsmen.

item.title: COMEDY Movie Quiz: Answers and Winners!
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Great job on the quiz, guys! Here are some stats: * 5,632 people took the quiz. * 1,456 people scored 100% (great job!) * The question most people got right (98% got it right) was…#4 * The question missed the most (only 56% got it right) was…#7. ANSWERS Q.3 In “Trading Places,” what were the wealthy Duke brothers’ first names? Rudolph and Randolph ***Randolph and Mortimer Mortimer and Michael Randolph and Michael      …
item.content:encoded:
Great job on the quiz, guys! Here are some stats:

* 5,632 people took the quiz.
* 1,456 people scored 100% (great job!)
* The question most people got right (98% got it right) was…#4
* The question missed the most (only 56% got it right) was…#7.

ANSWERS

Q.3
In “Trading Places,” what were the wealthy Duke brothers’ first names?

Rudolph and Randolph
***Randolph and Mortimer
Mortimer and Michael
Randolph and Michael

 
 
 
Q.4
In what movie does the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man begin destroying New York City?

Waiting for Guffman
Dirty Rotten Scoundrels
Planes, Trains, and Automobiles
***Ghostbusters

 
 
 
Q.5
“Jim never vomits at home.”

Annie Hall
***Airplane
Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy
Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery

 
 
 
Q.6
According to Buddy the Elf, the four food groups are candy, candy canes, candy corns and ___________?

Milk chocolate
Peanut butter
Marshmallows
***Syrup

 
 
 
Q.7
In the pro shop in Caddyshack, Rodney Dangerfield says if you buy a hat like Ted Knight’s, you get a free ______________!

Box of tees
***Bowl of soup
Golf lesson
Go
lf cart rental

 
 
 
Q.8
In “Dumb and Dumber,” what does Lloyd spike Harry’s drink with?

Salt
Sleep-All-Nite
Alcohol
***Turbo Lax

 
 
 
Q.9
What is Bill Murray’s occupation in Groundhog Day?

***Meteorologist
Schoolteacher
Dentist
Salesman

 
 
 
Q.10
What is Napoleon Dynamite’s favorite sport?

Volleyball
Bocce Ball
Racquetball
***Tetherball

 
 
 
Q.11
In what movie did Jennifer Aniston’s boss ask her to wear 37 pieces of flair?

Friends With Money
***Office Space
Along Came Polly
She’s the One

 
 
 
Q.12
“Put…zee candle…BACK!”

Dirty Rotten Scoundrels
Trading Places
***Young Frankenstein
Blazing Saddles

 
 
 
Q.13
What was John Belushi’s Delta Tau Chi name in “Animal House?”

***Bluto
Flounder
Pinto
Otter

 
 
 
Q.14
In “Wedding Crashers,” what does Will Ferrell’s character crash?

Baby showers
Bar Mitzvahs
***Funerals
Graduation parties

 
 
 
Q.15
What was significant about the campfire scene in “Blazing Saddles?”

All the cowboys had headaches.
All the cowboys were singing opera.
All the cowboys were wearing rhinestone hats.
***All the cowboys had gas.

 
 
 
Q.16
Who were “on a mission from God?”

Steve Martin and John Candy
***John Belushi and Dan Akroyd
Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor
Eddie Murphy and Dan Akroyd

 
 
 
Q.17
After ordering a new sports wagon, who gets stuck with a Family Truckster?

John Candy
Jim Belushi
Vince Vaughn
***Chevy Chase

 
 
 
Q.18
In “There’s Something About Mary,” what football player plays Mary’s former love interest?

Peyton Manning
John Elway
***Brett Favre
Joe Namath

 
 
 
Q.19
“Brothers don’t shake hands. Brothers gotta hug!”

Wedding Crashers
Dumb & Dumber
***Tommy Boy
Trading Places

 
 
 
Q.20
“Ooooh, behave!”

Ace Ventura
***Austin Powers
Napoleon Dynamite
Buddy the Elf

 

WINNERS

The first person who correctly answered all questions was…Sarah C!
The second place winner (selected from among the first 25 100% scores) was…Karen K!
The third place winner (selected from all 100% scores) was…Marie C!

Congrats, winners! Contact prizes@thepioneerwoman.com to claim your prizes.

item.title: Big COMEDY Movie Quiz: Enter Now!
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Time for the big COMEDY movie quiz. Have fun, guys!   TO ENTER To try your hand at the movie quiz, just answer the multiple choice movie questions below. Important: Select the best possible answer. In some cases, there may arguably be more than one right answer, but there will always be an overwhelmingly/obviously correct answer.   THE PRIZES 1. The first person to correctly answer all questions wins: One (1) 32 GB iPad with…
item.content:encoded:
Time for the big COMEDY movie quiz. Have fun, guys!

 

TO ENTER

To try your hand at the movie quiz, just answer the multiple choice movie questions below.

Important: Select the best possible answer. In some cases, there may arguably be more than one right answer, but there will always be an overwhelmingly/obviously correct answer.

 

THE PRIZES

1. The first person to correctly answer all questions wins:

One (1) 32 GB iPad with a Smart Cover color of his/her choice!

2. One randomly selected player from among the first 25 players to score 100% will receive a second place prize: a $200 Amazon.com gift card.

3. A third place winner will be randomly chosen among all contestants who score 100% and will win a $100 Amazon.com gift card.

Winners/answers will be revealed Sunday.

Good luck! (Quiz may take a moment to load below.)

 
Feel free to shout out your score in the Comments!

Take Our Survey!
